text:
Hi all, I’ve set up a meeting with our sales team to improve alignment with marketing. I’m wanting to get more internal buy in on content marketing, and I know that the sales team don’t use our articles or reports nearly as much as they should (they usually just use case studies and that’s it) and they very rarely share on linkedin etc. ( :broken_heart: )

Other than asking why they do or do not share certain pieces of content, and what they think is missing from marketing resources, are there any other questions I should be asking / points I should be making to persuade them to take a more active role in the company’s content strategy? :thinking_face:

elements.text: Hi all, I’ve set up a meeting with our sales team to improve alignment with marketing. )

Other than asking why they do or do not share certain pieces of content, and what they think is missing from marketing resources, are there any other questions I should be asking / points I should be making to persuade them to take a more active role in the company’s content strategy?

text: Heya <@U01DBK8NUCR>. First ask 'em why they don't use the content. Is it a pain or choke point for them in some way? Ask them what they feel would work, and then show them how your stuff can easily segway in. But that's IF you can get them to dialogue.  You might also have to look at internal politics, as might you be stepping on someones toes, who is not doing their job properly, but everyone is covering their butt.

elements.text: Heya

. First ask 'em why they don't use the content. Is it a pain or choke point for them in some way? Ask them what they feel would work, and then show them how your stuff can easily segway in. But that's IF you can get them to dialogue.  You might also have to look at internal politics, as might you be stepping on someones toes, who is not doing their job properly, but everyone is covering their butt.

text:
One thing that you could do with such a meeting (assuming you haven't already done something like this) is conduct some discovery on what kind of content would help with sales enablement.  In other words, a series of questions like:
• What questions come up over and over again on sales calls?
• What is the biggest objection you tend to have to overcome during the sales process?
• What customer misunderstandings tend to trigger refunds/churn?
• etc
With questions like this, you could build out content that treats sales as a secondary customer, and they'd probably not only share that content in a general sense, but also routinely send people to it during their interactions.

elements.text: One thing that you could do with such a meeting (assuming you haven't already done something like this) is conduct some discovery on what kind of content would help with sales enablement.  In other words, a series of questions like:

etc

With questions like this, you could build out content that treats sales as a secondary customer, and they'd probably not only share that content in a general sense, but also routinely send people to it during their interactions.

text: I say this from the perspective of someone who (for now, fingers crossed) handles all of my business's sales.  Sales conversations and discovery calls give rise to some no-brainers for content ideas.  If the SDRs record their calls, you could also ask for those recordings/transcriptions.  They tend to be goldmines of people asking questions about the product, the space, etc.

They tend to be goldmines of people asking questions about the product, the space, etc.
Excellent feedback

text:
Yes, all great stuff, thanks both! I’ve sent round a survey to begin with to get some feedback on how often theyre using the content, which pieces they use and what they think the biggest priorities are (all anonymous, so no need to cover their butt <@U01V7CQF8LC>! ).

Very helpfully our sales team do write ups of every call they have <@U017XD7H4P7>, including the objections. The tricky part is that we have a _very_ wide range of clients and use cases, so I should probably be plugging these into a spreadsheet and keeping tabs on how often they crop up — that’s my afternoon sorted! :nerd_face:

text: I generally wouldn't even ask about why they're not using the content — or even about what content they want (they always ask for case studies). Instead I've found the most value from digging into what is actually happening on their calls and where they feel pain

elements.text: I generally wouldn't even ask about why they're not using the content — or even about what content they want (they always ask for case studies). Instead I've found the most value from digging into what is actually happening on their calls and where they feel pain

text: <@U01DBK8NUCR>, would they be cool to use a simple Lead Management System, to tick off the dispositions - during the calls - that automatically goes in to a report/spreadsheet for you?

elements.text: , would they be cool to use a simple Lead Management System, to tick off the dispositions - during the calls - that automatically goes in to a report/spreadsheet for you?

text:
I also wouldn't go in asking about why they're not using content. Make it about them! I've done a ton of marketing-sales alignment over the past year. Through a lot of trial and error, I've come to a format for these meetings that works really well:
• Ask sales about their goals, what are they working towards? Once they give you an answer, tell em: awesome, I'm going to help you hit those numbers.
• Where do they see the best opportunity in the market to hit those goals?
• Who is the buying committee made up of? And who is the champion within the buying committee that must be on-board/excited about your product?
• What are the pains that that champion experiences? How does your product help relieve those pains?
Once you have that information, verify the info sales gave you (preferably through directly talking to customers), set up a plan for your content, and discuss this with sales. I wouldn't go in with a picture-perfect plan, but be open and ask for their feedback. It's all about making them excited about the content and making them co-owners of it.

elements.text: I also wouldn't go in asking about why they're not using content. Make it about them! I've done a ton of marketing-sales alignment over the past year. Through a lot of trial and error, I've come to a format for these meetings that works really well:
Ask sales about their goals, what are they working towards? Once they give you an answer, tell em: awesome, I'm going to help you hit those numbers.
Where do they see the best opportunity in the market to hit those goals?
Who is the buying committee made up of? And who is the champion within the buying committee that must be on-board/excited about your product?
What are the pains that that champion experiences? How does your product help relieve those pains?

Once you have that information, verify the info sales gave you (preferably through directly talking to customers), set up a plan for your content, and discuss this with sales. I wouldn't go in with a picture-perfect plan, but be open and ask for their feedback. It's all about making them excited about the content and making them co-owners of it.

text:
I recommend a mindset shift around this statement: "don’t use our articles or reports nearly as much as they should"

Should? Who came up with _should_? Marketing?

If that's the air you take to the conversation, there's a recipe for friction before you even get started. If you're leading the charge to help align marketing and sales, the best thing you can do is get to know THEIR processes, their shoulds. Speak in their language, understand their path to commission, etc. Lots of good advice above on this :)

text:
Yep, this is very true <@U01AHL8AGBB>! I guess “should” comes from the fact that we’re creating pieces of content to help them sell, and for whatever reason they’re not being used, which means we get very little ROI—you’re right that the language I used puts the onus on them rather than the content creators!

I’ve had some really interesting responses to the survey I circulated. One of them says “If I am spending 2 minutes on a chaser email, then adding 10 minutes hunting down a blog is too much time-cost. Though if there were a set of 10 “go-to” articles I could just template up an email to go with them.”

Though if there were a set of 10 “go-to” articles I could just template up an email to go with them.”

text: Aha, that's good intel—issue is less about content and more about internal distribution for this particular rep! any way you can  automate relevant links to blogs into a prospect's CRM entry? :eyes:

text:
This is all wonderful. My add: format matters. We unlocked something interesting when we started repurposing articles to one-sheeters, outreach templates, and slides — because thats how our sales team preferred to communicate info (not linkedin or blog post links).

Suggestion:
1- Ask them what their most shared resource is and take note of how its formatted.

2 - As others have said, sit in on a sales calls and see how they communicate information to the client.

3 - Sum up every blog post or content asset for the sales team. (Example: “This post is good for our new users for reasons X Y Z”)

text:
+1 to all the replies saying to lean into how your work supports them and outlining the opportunities to influence future plans.

I can only add a few extra details:
• *Follow up:* After hearing what they have to say and gathering inputs, make sure you're regularly sharing plans.
• *Over communicate before publishing:* Establish a regular cadence and specific channels to keep sales/cs in the loop about upcoming publishes. 
• *Educate and support:* Don't just tell sales/cs that content will soon be published. Tell them WHY it's valuable and consider drafting copy that enables them to share it with prospects. 
• *Ask for feedback:* Ask SDRs/BDRs about their meetings and how content played a role in their evaluations/pitches. 
• *Shine a light on success:* Don't just share monthly and quarterly results. If you have marketing automation, look at recently won deals that touched your content and craft a story that you'll share with the entire org. We called this "Journey to SQL" at Eventbrite and it was pivotal in aligning our teams.

text:
One more thing related to internal distro! If you have the budget, look into Highspot and Bambu (Social Sprout).

At Udemy, we use the former as a content library/repository for sales/cs and the latter to scale employee advocacy of our content.

text:
This thread has so much good advice!!! A lotta gold in here :moneybag:

The only thing I might add is _if_ you have someone in a sales ops or revenue ops role, there's potential to form a really valuable partnership. Folks in those roles care a lot about making sellers more efficient and would likely have intrinsic motivation that align with your own.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz
